snippet.textDisplay: Dr. Burton, I've been trying to get an answer to my question maybe you could help. In the game bubble ball by robert nay you can select a different ball color in options. The ball would then be on level 1 to start the game. Would you be able to do a video or write the code I can't find anyone who knows how. Thanks
snippet.textOriginal: Dr. Burton, I've been trying to get an answer to my question maybe you could help. In the game bubble ball by robert nay you can select a different ball color in options. The ball would then be on level 1 to start the game. Would you be able to do a video or write the code I can't find anyone who knows how. Thanks

snippet.textDisplay: @David Dr. Burton would you tell me where my mistake is, options or level 1scene? Thanks
snippet.textOriginal: @David Dr. Burton would you tell me where my mistake is, options or level 1scene? Thanks

snippet.textDisplay: @David Sorry if it was too much code Dr. Burton.
snippet.textOriginal: @David Sorry if it was too much code Dr. Burton.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Brian Burton Dr. Burton I'm going to copy & paste the way I entered the code. 
Starting in the options scene I'm using only a green and blue png ball. 

function scene:create( event )
local sceneGroup = self.view

	local background = display.newImageRect( "background.png", 650, 450 )
	background.x = display.contentCenterX
	background.y = display.contentCenterY
	
physics.start()
physics.pause()
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
_G.myAvatar = ""
local titleText = display.newText( "Select Your Avatar", 250, 101, native.systemFont, 20 )



local greenBall = display.newImageRect( "greenBall.png", 25, 25 ) 
greenBall.avatar = "greenBall.png"
greenBall.x = display.contentCenterX-200
greenBall.y = display.contentCenterY+40
physics.addBody( greenBall, "static", { density=1.0, radius=12 } ) 

local blueBall = display.newImageRect( "blueBall.png", 25, 25 ) 
blueBall.avatar = "blueBall.png" 
blueBall.x = display.contentCenterX
blueBall.y = display.contentCenterY+40
physics.addBody( blueBall, "static", { density=1.0, radius=12 } ) 

local function onObjectTap( event )
			myAvatar = event.target.avatar
			print( event.target.avatar .. " selected")
		end

greenBall:addEventListener( "tap", onObjectTap )
blueBall:addEventListener( "tap", onObjectTap ) 
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
sceneGroup:insert( greenBall )
sceneGroup:insert( blueBall ) 

end




The rest of your code is on the level1 scene and the error message appears as soon as I tap the level1 button. 

local avatarText = display.newText("Your Avatar is:", 350 750)
local avatar = display.newImage(myAvatar) 
avatar.x = 350
avatar.y = 900

sceneGroup:insert( avatarText )
sceneGroup:insert( avatar )

end

I'll wait to add the error messages.  Thanks

snippet.textDisplay: @Brian Burton Mr. Burton, would it be too much to ask if you would write an example using by name? It's taking me a long time to learn how to code. Thanks

snippet.textDisplay: Hi David.  Yes, I can do that.  The short answer (without a video) is that you store the selected color in a variable, then apply it to the object using object:setFillColor(variable).  You can store the color using rgb values or by name (i.e. 'red', 'grey', 'black', etc)
snippet.textOriginal: Hi David.  Yes, I can do that.  The short answer (without a video) is that you store the selected color in a variable, then apply it to the object using object:setFillColor(variable).  You can store the color using rgb values or by name (i.e. 'red', 'grey', 'black', etc)
